identity_management.score: AWS IAM, bucket ACL, object ACL

S3.FC1.name: Object operations
S3.FC1.description: You can upload, download, and delete virtually any number of objects to an external S3 bucket for which you are authorized.
S3.FC1.long_description: You can upload, download, and delete virtually any number of objects to an external S3 bucket for which you are authorized. Amazon S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) enable you to manage access to objects. Each object has an ACL attached to it as a sub-resource. It defines which AWS accounts or groups are granted access and the type of access. When a request is received against a resource, Amazon S3 checks the corresponding ACL to ensure the requester has the necessary access permissions (ref).

S3.FC4.name: Tag on versioned objects
S3.FC4.description: You can tag each version of an object (ref).

S3.FC5.name: Bucket
S3.FC5.description: To upload your data into your AWS account, you must create an S3 bucket in one of the AWS Regions.

S3.FC6.name: Bucket versioning
S3.FC6.description: Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket (ref).
S3.FC6.long_description: Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your Amazon S3 bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from unintended user actions and application failures (ref).

S3.FC8.name: Bucket ACL
S3.FC8.description: Amazon S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) enable you to manage access to buckets (ref).
S3.FC8.long_description: [NOT RECOMMENDED] Amazon S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) enable you to manage access to buckets. Each bucket has an ACL attached to it as a sub-resource. It defines which AWS accounts or groups are granted access and the type of access. When a request is received against a resource, Amazon S3 checks the corresponding ACL to ensure the requester has the necessary access permissions (ref).

S3.FC9.name: ACL on versioned objects
S3.FC9.description: Amazon S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) enable you to manage access to object versions (ref).

S3.FC10.name: Bucket policy
S3.FC10.description: For your bucket, you can add a bucket policy to grant other AWS accounts or IAM users permissions for the bucket and the objects in it. Any object permissions apply only to the objects that the bucket owner creates.

S3.FC11.name: Analytics
S3.FC11.description: You can analyze storage access patterns to decide the storage class (ref).

S3.FC12.name: Inventory
S3.FC12.description: You can create a report on your storage, including object metadata or versions (ref).

S3.FC13.name: Lifecycle
S3.FC13.description: You can manage the lifecycle of your data to reduce storage costs (ref).

S3.FC14.name: Metrics
S3.FC14.description: You can configure metrics to get additional insights into your usage (ref).

S3.FC15.name: Replication
S3.FC15.description: Replication enables the automatic and asynchronous copying of objects from one bucket to another bucket (ref).
S3.FC15.long_description: Replication enables automatic and asynchronous copying of objects from one bucket to another. It can be cross-region or within the same region. Buckets configured for replication can be in the same AWS account or in different accounts. It is usually used for backing up S3 data, data centralization, or for multi-region applications.

S3.FC16.name: Website
S3.FC16.description: You can host a static website on Amazon S3. On a static website, individual web pages include static content. They might also contain client-side scripts (ref).

S3.FC17.name: S3 Object Lock
S3.FC17.description: You can use S3 Object Lock to store objects using a write-once-read-many (WORM) model (ref). Creating a bucket with S3 Object Lock will enable versioning even without permissions.

S3.FC18.name: Transfer Acceleration
S3.FC18.description: You can use Transfer Acceleration to improve the performance of long-distance transfers (ref).

S3.FC19.name: S3 access logging
S3.FC19.description: Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests made to a bucket.
S3.FC19.long_description: Server access logging provides detailed records for the requests made to a bucket. CloudTrail S3 data events are preferred due to the more reliable delivery timing, consistency, supporting KMS encryption, and S3 Object Lock (full comparison); however, the website endpoint is not recorded on S3 data events, some SIEM modules might be more feature-rich with S3 access logs, and access logging is free besides storage.

S3.FC20.name: Notification
S3.FC20.description: You can receive notifications when certain events happen in your bucket.
S3.FC20.long_description: You can receive notifications when certain events happen in your bucket. Notifications can be sent cross-account (ref).

S3.FC21.name: Torrent
S3.FC21.description: You can use the BitTorrent protocol to retrieve objects (ref).
S3.FC21.long_description: [NOT RECOMMENDED] You can use the BitTorrent protocol to retrieve objects (ref). It is only available in the AWS Regions launched before May 30, 2016. The seed rate is 100 KB. After April 29, 2022, BitTorrent clients will no longer connect to Amazon S3.

S3.FC22.name: CORS
S3.FC22.description: You can create a CORS configuration with rules that identify the origins you will allow to access your bucket, the operations (HTTP methods) supported for each origin, and other operation-specific information.
S3.FC22.long_description: [NOT RECOMMENDED] To configure your bucket to allow cross-origin requests, you create a CORS configuration, which is an XML document with rules that identify the origins that you will allow to access your bucket, the operations (HTTP methods) that will support for each origin, and other operation-specific information. This feature class is NOT RECOMMENDED to be activated since it is all HTTP. Prefer the use of CDN (e.g., CloudFront), API Gateway, and/or WAF fronting S3 buckets.

S3.FC23.name: Bucket default encryption
S3.FC23.description: You can set default encryption on a bucket so that all new objects are encrypted when stored in the bucket.

S3.FC24.name: Public Access Block (bucket)
S3.FC24.description: S3 Block Public Access (bucket) provides controls at the individual S3 bucket level to ensure objects never have public access.

S3.FC25.name: Public Access Block (account)
S3.FC25.description: S3 Block Public Access (account) provides controls across an entire AWS account to ensure objects never have public access.

S3.FC26.name: Access point
S3.FC26.description: Access points are named network endpoints that are attached to buckets, which you can use to perform S3 object operations.
S3.FC26.long_description: Access points are named network endpoints that are attached to buckets that you can use to perform S3 object operations. Only certain operations and AWS services are compatible (ref). S3 access points aren't currently compatible with Amazon CloudWatch metrics.

S3.FC27.name: Batch
S3.FC27.description: S3 Batch Operations performs large-scale Batch Operations on Amazon S3 objects.

S3.FC28.name: Other uses
S3.FC28.description: Others can use their S3 service to impact you in some way.

S3.FC29.name: Legal hold
S3.FC29.description: A legal hold provides the same protection as a retention period but has no expiration date. S3 Object Lock must be activated on the bucket.
S3.FC29.long_description: A legal hold provides the same protection as a retention period, but it has no expiration date. Instead, a legal hold remains in place until you explicitly remove it. Legal holds are independent of retention periods.

S3.FC30.name: S3 Object Ownership
S3.FC30.description: S3 Object Ownership enables bucket owners to automatically assume ownership of objects uploaded to their buckets by other AWS accounts.
S3.FC30.long_description: Enables bucket owners to automatically assume ownership of objects uploaded to their buckets by other AWS accounts. When an object is put with an ACL of "bucket-owner-full-control", the object will be fully owned by the target bucket owner. If the ACL is added later, ownership is retained by the object owner (ref).

S3.FC31.name: S3 Storage Lens
S3.FC31.description: S3 Storage Lens provides a single view of object storage use and activity across your entire S3 storage.

S3.FC32.name: S3 Object Lambda
S3.FC32.description: S3 Object Lambda enables users to apply their custom code to process the output of a standard S3 request by automatically invoking a Lambda function.

S3.FC33.name: Multi-Region Access Points
S3.FC33.description: S3 Multi-Region Access Points provide a single global endpoint to access a dataset that spans multiple S3 buckets in different AWS Regions or in different AWS accounts.

S3.FC34.name: Tagging (for Storage Lens group only)
S3.FC34.description: When you configure your Storage Lens group, you can optionally add AWS resource tags to the group.

S3.FC35.name: FIS actions
S3.FC35.description: In AWS Fault Injection Service, the action aws:s3:bucket-pause-replication can pause S3 replication from the experiment AWS Region to the destination AWS Region for the targeted buckets. Review FIS ThreatModel for more information.

S3.FC36.name: Attribute-based access control (ABAC) for general purpose buckets
S3.FC36.description: ABAC for general purpose buckets is an Amazon S3 feature that allows access decisions to be made based on matching attributes such as tags between IAM principals and S3 buckets.

S3.T1.name: Bucket takeover to gather data
S3.T1.description: Bucket names are globally unique and can be recreated after 1 hour from deletion in another AWS account. An attacker can recreate the same bucket name of a deleted bucket you used to own to collect any new data uploaded by a non-updated party (ref), do a DNS takeover (using a non-deleted CNAME / CloudFront origin to the bucket), or use remaining permissions to exfiltrate data.

S3.T2.name: Unauthorized access to data or loss of control of SSE-C encrypted data via bucket replication
S3.T2.description: Replication allows you to replicate objects and their metadata and change ownership. The configuration only focuses on new objects (old objects replication requires S3 Batch Replication). An attacker can configure replication on a versioned bucket to replicate objects (or their metadata or tagging) in a bucket they control to exfiltrate data. As objects encrypted via SSE-C are also replicated without additional configuration or access requirements, an attacker can then decrypt them in their own bucket if they have the SSE-C key.

S3.T3.name: Exfiltrate your data hosted on an external bucket by using compromised IAM credentials accessed over the Internet
S3.T3.description: IAM credentials can be compromised. An attacker can use a compromised but authorized credential to download your object from an external bucket via the public endpoint or their VPC endpoint.

S3.T4.name: Grant unauthorized access to a private bucket by changing its bucket ACL
S3.T4.description: Bucket ACL can be used to give access to bucket information, list objects, and overwrite or delete objects. An attacker can change the bucket ACL to destroy or modify data, or exfiltrate data via the object name (1 KB).

S3.T5.name: Unauthorized upload of a private object to an accessible (e.g., public) bucket you do not own
S3.T5.description: S3 buckets can be public for a legitimate reason. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can upload sensitive data to an accessible bucket (e.g., public) you do not own to make it accessible to exfiltrate data.

S3.T6.name: Unauthorized modification of an object to become public or accessible in a private bucket you do not own by changing its object ACL
S3.T6.description: Bucket authority only prevails over object ACL when the object access is explicitly denied (ref). An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the object ACL to make it public or accessible to themselves.

S3.T7.name: Exfiltrate data to an attacker bucket via a public endpoint
S3.T7.description: S3 allows IAM entities to upload data to a bucket in other AWS accounts if they have the necessary IAM permissions. An attacker can use one of your IAM entities to upload data to one of their buckets. If the attacker does not control the object ACL, they can use the names of objects (1 KB).

S3.T8.name: Exfiltrate data by using an S3 VPC endpoint to upload data to an attacker's bucket using an internal IAM entity
S3.T8.description: VPC endpoints for S3 allow IAM entities to connect from a VPC to any S3 bucket without an Internet Gateway. An attacker can exfiltrate pre-collected data to an external S3 bucket via a VPC endpoint, using an internal IAM entity they control. If the attacker does not control the object ACL, they can use the names of objects (1 KB).

S3.T9.name: Exfiltrate data by uploading it to an attacker bucket using a non-authenticated user or an unauthorized external IAM entity via one of your S3 VPC endpoints
S3.T9.description: VPC endpoints for S3 allow any entity to connect from a VPC to any S3 bucket without an Internet Gateway. An attacker can exfiltrate data to an external S3 bucket via one of your VPC endpoints, using an unauthenticated user or their own external IAM entity. Note that some external IAM entities might be authorized if provided by one of your business partners.

S3.T10.name: Exfiltrate data by using the public endpoint to upload data to an attacker's bucket, using external credentials
S3.T10.description: AWS authenticates per AWS account. An attacker can use their own credentials to exfiltrate data to external S3 buckets through the S3 public endpoint. It can be a non-authenticated user as well.

S3.T11.name: Move prod data into a non-prod environment
S3.T11.description: Multiple types of environments are usually operated in AWS. An attacker can move the data from a secure location (e.g., production) to a less secure location (e.g., dev).

S3.T12.name: Intercept data in transit to an external bucket
S3.T12.description: S3 allows communication over HTTP. An attacker can intercept the traffic you send to an external bucket to read or modify the data.

S3.T13.name: Intercept data in transit on an S3 website endpoint
S3.T13.description: S3 website endpoint is serving HTTP only. An attacker can intercept the traffic you send to an external bucket to read the data.

S3.T14.name: Use a bucket to upload malware or modify an object to include malware
S3.T14.description: S3 buckets are commonly used to distribute software. An attacker can upload malware to a bucket to better position it for later use or directly change an object to include malware (example).

S3.T15.name: Embed client-side script malware in a bucket website
S3.T15.description: S3 website enables users to be served client-side scripts (e.g., JavaScript). An attacker can upload a client-side script with malware (e.g., cryptomining) to the visitors.

S3.T16.name: Files encrypted for ransomware
S3.T16.description: S3 provides several types of encryption where the key is not operated by AWS (e.g., SSE-KMS with Bring Your Own Key). An attacker can encrypt all the data stored in S3 to ransom the data owner for the decryption key (blogs: 1 and 2). Alternatively, an attacker can change the default encryption key, for a similar effect on any new data uploaded.

S3.T17.name: Destroy or modify primary data
S3.T17.description: S3 provides high durability by design (11 9s). However, data can still be deleted by the customer. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can use their access to destroy (or modify) primary data located on S3, affecting the ability of the business to operate (for example, Code Spaces).

S3.T18.name: Exfiltrate data by using tags
S3.T18.description: Objects and buckets can have tags. An attacker can use these features to exfiltrate data.

S3.T19.name: Recon of AWS root account emails using the email ACL grantee feature
S3.T19.description: S3 allows you to add root account emails to an ACL (ref, note that it will be discontinued on Oct 1st, 2025), and also resolve the given canonical ID into an AWS account ID (via a bucket policy, which automatically resolves a canonical ID into an ARN). An attacker can use trial-and-error to discover existing AWS root account emails and related AWS account IDs (even if you do not use the region where the feature is available), and use this information to launch another attack (e.g., phishing).

S3.T20.name: Use CloudFront to access a private bucket
S3.T20.description: CloudFront distributions can use S3 buckets or access points as their origin. An attacker can connect a CloudFront distribution to a private S3 bucket to gain access to it. Note: S3 resource policies can allow a "cloudfront.amazonaws.com" principal, which could allow any distribution if not restricted.

S3.T21.name: Exfiltrate data stored on S3 via AWS services
S3.T21.description: A number of AWS services use S3 for storage, including cross-account S3 buckets. Services with IAM roles (e.g., SageMaker) will give ownership to the target AWS account, removing ownership protection. An attacker can use those services to exfiltrate data.

S3.T22.name: Increase S3 costs by hotlinking or excessive downloading
S3.T22.description: S3 charges for hosting and data transfer out. An attacker can hotlink your content hosted on S3 on another page to avoid paying the S3 bills (ref) or download your public data excessively to increase your bills (especially doing partial downloads on large objects).

S3.T23.name: Phishing using trademarks
S3.T23.description: S3 provides URLs to buckets using the bucket name (i.e., "mybucket.s3.amazonaws.com"). An attacker can create a bucket with the name of your trademark to phish users.

S3.T24.name: Recon on valid AWS accounts or IAM principals
S3.T24.description: AWS provides error messages in AWS IAM or S3 bucket policy operations that can be used for basic recon. An attacker can discover whether an AWS account with a specific AWS account ID or IAM principal exists by modifying the policy of their own IAM resource or S3 bucket to grant some rights to that target AWS account or IAM principal (ref, ref2).

S3.T25.name: Delete objects by using lifecycle
S3.T25.description: Lifecycle allows you to delete objects after their configured expiry. An attacker can use a lifecycle configuration to destroy data.

S3.T26.name: Unauthorized object restored into an unauthorized bucket
S3.T26.description: Objects can be stored in S3 Glacier. An attacker can restore an object to an unauthorized S3 bucket to collect or exfiltrate data.

S3.T27.name: Disrupt workflow by manipulating ETag
S3.T27.description: ETags include the MD5 of the file but not consistently and can be used by developers to verify the integrity of a file. An attacker can affect an upload function to change the ETag of a file to disrupt a workflow downstream.

S3.T28.name: Unauthorized collection of data by swapping access points
S3.T28.description: Access points can be deleted and recreated with the same name, and therefore the same ARN. An attacker can delete an access point and recreate the same one on a bucket they control to collect/modify data, or make it accessible over the Internet.

S3.T29.name: Clickjacking on S3 website
S3.T29.description: S3 does not enforce certain security headers by default. An attacker can use an iFrame on your website to trick users into interacting with their own scripts.

S3.T30.name: Use AWS services to access data in S3
S3.T30.description: A number of AWS services can access S3 to execute their functions. An attacker can use them to collect data using their service roles or service-linked roles.

S3.T31.name: Upload to an authorized external bucket but in an incorrect AWS account
S3.T31.description: Bucket names are globally unique. An attacker can take over a legitimate external bucket and deceive you into sending data to their bucket.

S3.T32.name: Recon on the AWS Region of a bucket
S3.T32.description: Error messages can give some information about specific buckets. An attacker who knows the bucket name can find its AWS Region. To find the AWS Region, use "aws s3 presign bucket-name/whatever", go to the presign link, and the error message will give you the region, if not in the right region.

S3.T33.name: Gain access by modifying or deleting important object tags
S3.T33.description: Tags can be used for various reasons, including security classification or access management (via ABAC). An attacker can change the tagging of an object to another value, enabling them to execute another attack.

S3.T34.name: Intercept data in transit to an internal bucket
S3.T34.description: S3 allows communication over HTTP. An attacker can intercept the traffic you send to an internal bucket in order to read or modify the data.

S3.T35.name: Use of less secure or old S3 features
S3.T35.description: S3 was launched in 2006, and its features have evolved. An attacker can use older features that have been proven less secure by AWS (e.g., certain API configurations, SigV2, path-style model), but are still maintained for retro-compatibility.

S3.T36.name: Object made public or accessible in a private bucket you own by changing its object ACL
S3.T36.description: Bucket authority only prevails over object ACL when the object access is explicitly denied by the bucket authority (ref). An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the object ACL to make the object public or accessible to themselves to exfiltrate or modify the data.

S3.T37.name: Grant unauthorized access to a private bucket by changing its bucket policy
S3.T37.description: Bucket policies can enable access to objects owned by buckets. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change a bucket policy to make the content of the bucket either accessible (via public endpoints, cross-account VPC endpoints, or cross-account access points) or to block all principals (leading to the need to use root to delete the policy) to impact the availability of any applications using the bucket.

S3.T38.name: Reduce bucket security by deleting the bucket policy
S3.T38.description: Bucket policy can deny access to objects, as it supersedes the object's authority. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can delete the bucket policy and make the content less secure.

S3.T39.name: Exfiltrate data by using compromised IAM credentials from the Internet
S3.T39.description: IAM credentials can be compromised (directly or using presigned URL). An attacker can use a compromised but authorized IAM credential to download your object from an internal bucket via the public endpoint (using or not their own VPC endpoint).

S3.T40.name: Increase bill by creating incomplete multipart uploads
S3.T40.description: By default, when a multipart upload is initiated but not completed, S3 will keep it (ref). An attacker can upload a large amount of data without completing it while being hard to detect.

S3.T41.name: Exfiltrate data via event notification
S3.T41.description: Event notification sends the key to any configured SQS, SNS, or Lambda (cross-account), or EventBridge (same account). An attacker can use the name of objects (1 KB) to exfiltrate data.

S3.T42.name: Exfiltrate data via inventory
S3.T42.description: Inventory sends the object names (i.e., keys) to any configured S3 bucket or other metadata. An attacker can use the names of objects (1 KB) to exfiltrate data or use the metadata to conduct reconnaissance.

S3.T43.name: Loss of ownership of an object
S3.T43.description: S3 Object Ownership enables a bucket receiver to convert a bucket-owner-full-control ACL into an ownership transfer (for a new object); additionally, a bucket can convert all the objects to be owned by the bucket owner. An attacker can modify the receiver bucket to remove your object ACL control on an object and remove your access to this object.

S3.T44.name: Exfiltrate, modify, or delete objects using Batch
S3.T44.description: S3 Batch Operations require an IAM role (with a proper trust policy), and can run operations including replicating existing objects, copying, or replacing/deleting object tags. An attacker can use Batch to copy or modify objects to exfiltrate or change the access management of an object (if relying on a tag).

S3.T46.name: Hijack a connection with an Object Lambda
S3.T46.description: Object Lambda is invoked between the access point and the object. An attacker can configure a Lambda to modify, snoop, or exfiltrate data.

S3.T47.name: Increase the bill by restoring a large amount of data
S3.T47.description: Restore costs can be amplified by the size and the type (i.e., expedited). An attacker can restore lots of data to generate costs.

S3.T48.name: Affect data protection by removing versioning
S3.T48.description: Versioning can be used as the first level of integrity protection. An attacker can suspend versioning to affect the data protection of a bucket.

S3.T49.name: Affect data protection by removing replication
S3.T49.description: Replication can be used as a level of integrity protection and backup. An attacker can remove replication to affect data protection.

S3.T50.name: DoS by blocking traffic using bucket ACL
S3.T50.description: Bucket ACL can allow access (e.g., for CloudFront access logs). An attacker can remove an existing permission to deny legitimate access to the bucket.

S3.T51.name: Evade detection by disabling S3 access logs via a bucket ACL change
S3.T51.description: S3 access logs can be used by SIEM to detect abnormal behaviors. An attacker can disable S3 access logs via bucket ACL changes on the logging destination bucket to evade detection.

S3.T52.name: Reduce bucket security by modifying the bucket's Public Access Block
S3.T52.description: Bucket Public Access Block protects individual buckets from leakage (e.g., object ACL set to public). An attacker can remove this protection by modifying the bucket Public Access Block.

S3.T53.name: Reduce bucket security by modifying the account's Public Access Block
S3.T53.description: Account Public Access Block protects all buckets of an AWS account from leakage (e.g., object ACL set to public). An attacker can remove this protection by modifying the account's Public Access Block.

S3.T54.name: Grant unauthorized access to a bucket by changing or deleting one of its access points' policies
S3.T54.description: Access point policies can enable access to objects owned by buckets. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the access point policy and make the content accessible.

S3.T55.name: Grant unauthorized access to buckets by changing the Multi-Region Access Point policy
S3.T55.description: Multi-Region Access Point policy can enable access to objects owned by the bucket. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the Multi-Region Access Point policy and make the content accessible.

S3.T56.name: Gain unauthorized access to buckets trusting all Multi-Region Access Points
S3.T56.description: Buckets used by Multi-Region Access Points can be configured to delegate their access to any MRAP using the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount". An attacker can create an MRAP, add any misconfigured bucket, and gain access to it.

S3.T57.name: Uncontrolled change in IAM-managed policies
S3.T57.description: AWS managed policies can be attached to your IAM entities, but their permissions are managed by AWS. An attacker (including an AWS insider via a service-linked role) can use an overprivileged managed policy to execute an attack.

S3.T58.name: Evade detection by disabling S3 access logs via bucket policy change or removal
S3.T58.description: S3 access logs can be used by SIEM to detect abnormal behaviors. An attacker can disable S3 access logs via bucket policy changes on the logging destination bucket to evade detection.

S3.T59.name: Evade detection by modifying S3 access logs
S3.T59.description: S3 access logs can be used by SIEM to detect abnormal behaviors. An attacker can modify or disable S3 access logs to evade detection.

S3.T60.name: Create an exfiltration vector via cross-account access point
S3.T60.description: Access points from a given AWS account can be connected to a cross-account bucket. An attacker can create an access point connected to a bucket they control to exfiltrate data.

S3.T61.name: Increase costs and compliance risks by enabling S3 Object Lock in compliance mode
S3.T61.description: Existing objects or buckets can be modified to have S3 Object Lock enabled. An attacker can enable it in compliance mode to lock any existing objects or new objects, increasing costs due to unnecessary data storage and potentially causing compliance risks if data is retained beyond its legally required period.

S3.T62.name: Recon on the security boundaries and resource names through detailed access denial messages
S3.T62.description: Enhanced access-denied messages include detailed response fields about which condition or permission prevented access. They are available only within the same AWS account or within AWS Organizations. An attacker can repeatedly attempt to access buckets with different parameters or identities and gather specific reasons for denial or existing resource names (using the presence or absence of the enhanced access-denied messages), leading to the discovery of deployed security configurations and buckets in AWS Organizations.

S3.T63.name: Disrupting object writes by disabling customer-managed encryption on a bucket using SSE-C
S3.T63.description: Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys [SSE-C] can be blocked on individual general purpose buckets [will be the default from April 2026]. An attacker can change the encryption configuration to disable SSE-C on a bucket using it, resulting in objects failing to be written.

S3.T64.name: Privilege escalation by enabling ABAC on general purpose buckets
S3.T64.description: ABAC allows access to be managed by tags on general purpose buckets (disabled by default). An attacker can enable ABAC on a general purpose bucket that was previously not managed through it, allowing for some policy combinations to escalate privileges on the bucket and its objects.

S3.T65.name: Disrupting access by switching the object encryption type or its KMS key
S3.T65.description: An object's encryption type can be changed in some conditions (SSE-S3 to SSE-KMS, or between different KMS keys). The KMS key must be in the same AWS account (via API), or the same AWS Organization (via AWS Support). An attacker can change the encryption type or the KMS key for an object, causing loss of access to the object for applications that do not have permissions to use the new KMS key.

S3.CO2.description: Block S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security

S3.CO3.description: Enable S3 data events in AWS CloudTrail

S3.CO4.description: Monitor S3 with Amazon GuardDuty and Macie

S3.CO5.description: Identify and ensure the protection of all external buckets hosting your objects

S3.CO6.description: Model the threats on all AWS services accessing S3

S3.CO7.description: Limit and monitor access via S3 VPC endpoints

S3.CO8.description: Limit the IAM entities allowed to use the IAM actions required to execute attacks

S3.CO9.description: Block requests with KMS keys from unauthorized AWS accounts

S3.CO10.description: Block changes to make an object public via object ACL

S3.CO15.description: Identify and ensure the protection of all internal buckets hosting your objects

S3.CO19.description: Have a process to apply legal holds

S3.CO20.description: Protect data integrity using S3 Object Lock

S3.CO24.description: Block all requests not using an HTTP authorization header, if not explicitly authorized

S3.CO26.description: Scan objects used for input/output of a workflow for malware

S3.CO28.description: Control the data collected and the storage location of the inventory

S3.CO29.description: Limit access from only authorized VPCs

S3.CO31.description: Protect and/or claim your domains and trademarks/copyrights

S3.CO32.description: Restrict access point access to VPCs when in use

S3.CO33.description: Restrict Batch access using dedicated IAM roles

S3.CO34.description: Enforce only authorized Object Lambda Access Point and associated access

S3.CO35.description: Deploy only authorized S3 websites and place them behind a CDN

S3.CO38.description: Ensure all requests are blocked from unauthorized service roles

S3.CO39.description: Enforce S3 server access logging on buckets

S3.CO40.description: Restrict access points to authorized AWS accounts

S3.C1.description: Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorized TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control (e.g., by denying all unencrypted requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False, or by using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s), using an SCP on your AWS Organization root node).
S3.C1.testing: Make an unencrypted S3 API call; it should be denied.

S3.C2.description: Verify the control blocking unencrypted requests and unauthorized TLS versions from IAM entities you control (e.g., an SCP on your AWS Organization's root node) is properly implemented.
S3.C2.testing: Remove the control blocking unencrypted requests and unauthorized TLS version(s) (e.g., the SCP on your root node); it should be detected.

S3.C3.description: Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorized TLS version(s) from VPC endpoints you control (e.g., by denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False, or by using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s), on the VPC endpoint policy).
S3.C3.testing: Make an unencrypted AWS API call from one of your VPCs with a VPC endpoint; it should be denied.

S3.C4.description: Monitor and investigate all requests made with HTTP (e.g., via CloudTrail S3 data events with the lack of additionalEventData.CipherSuite).
S3.C4.testing: Make an unencrypted AWS API call from one of your VPCs with VPC endpoint; it should be detected.

S3.C5.description: Verify a statement exists on all your VPC endpoint policies denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False or using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s).
S3.C5.testing: Create/remove the statement on a VPC endpoint policy denying 1) all unencrypted requests or 2) unauthorized TLS version(s); it should be detected.

S3.C6.description: Block all unencrypted requests to the buckets you control (e.g., by denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False, or by using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s), on their bucket policy or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account).
S3.C6.testing: Make an unencrypted AWS API call to a bucket you control; it should be denied.

S3.C7.description: Verify all S3 bucket policies block unencrypted traffic (e.g., using the AWS Config rule: S3_BUCKET_SSL_REQUESTS_ONLY) and unauthorized versions of TLS.
S3.C7.testing: Remove the statement on a bucket policy 1) denying all unencrypted requests and 2) denying unauthorized TLS versions; it should be detected.

S3.C8.description: Block S3 endpoints (DNS and IP ranges) in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet (e.g., firewalls or a cloud interception proxy), including via Internet Gateway, to force the use of VPC endpoints. It will block data-plane transfer. Note: AWS Management Console stays functional as it proxies non-data-plane requests (via "console.aws.amazon.com").
S3.C8.testing: Request the evidence of the implementation of blocking S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security (e.g., firewalls) and tests of its effectiveness.

S3.C9.description: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions, and buckets (e.g., production, with sensitive data). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel.
S3.C9.testing: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events.

S3.C10.description: Enable and monitor S3 protection in Amazon GuardDuty in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using the GuardDuty ThreatModel. Ensure findings are investigated (e.g., using Amazon Detective).
S3.C10.testing: Request the GuardDuty ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling, monitoring, investigating, and protecting S3 use.

S3.C11.description: Track all buckets you don't control that host your objects, define their data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), determine their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assurance of their protection (e.g., through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).
S3.C11.testing: Request the list of all external buckets authorized to host your objects, their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), their data classification, and the mechanism used to ensure the security of those buckets.

S3.C12.description: Allow only authorized ACLs on objects for buckets you don't control (e.g., using IAM and VPC endpoint policy with the ACL conditions).
S3.C12.testing: Put an object with an unauthorized ACL; it should be denied.

S3.C13.description: Monitor that only authorized external buckets are used (e.g., via CloudTrail S3 data events in resources[].accountId and resources[].ARN). Both account ID and bucket name must be verified.
S3.C13.testing: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C14.description: Scan all data before uploading to an external bucket to ensure the classification of the data is aligned with the bucket classification (e.g., using Macie).
S3.C14.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring all data is scanned for proper data classification before upload to an external bucket, 2) its records of execution for all object upload flows, and 3) the plan to move any older object upload flows.

S3.C15.description: Request access via an S3 access point on a bucket you don't own, if compatible with your interaction with the bucket (e.g., not through an unsupported AWS service).
S3.C15.testing: Request the documented reasons why the access point was not implemented in the use case.

S3.C16.description: Analyze and protect all AWS services accessing S3 (e.g., via ThreatModel). Enforce use in VPC only, whenever possible.
S3.C16.testing: Request the ThreatModels for all AWS services using S3.

S3.C17.description: For each VPC, maintain a list of AWS Organizations, OUs, and/or AWS accounts where IAM entities are authorized to access S3.
S3.C17.testing: For each VPC, request the list of AWS Organizations, OU, and/or AWS account(s), where IAM entities are authorized to access S3, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C18.description: For each VPC with an IAM entity allowed to use S3, secure them with the VPC ThreatModel (e.g., modification of VPC endpoints, VPC endpoint policy, routing table, Security Groups).
S3.C18.testing: Request how the VPC ThreatModel for S3 is being applied.

S3.C19.description: Block any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organization, OU, and/or AWS account from calling S3 from your VPCs by adding a deny statement in the S3 VPC endpoint policy for each VPC, with the condition using "aws:PrincipalOrgPaths" (ref) including the full Org IDs, as those are globally unique.
S3.C19.testing: For each VPC, make an API call with an IAM entity that is not part of its authorized AWS Organizations paths; it should be denied.

S3.C20.description: Verify all S3 VPC endpoints are blocking any IAM entity not belonging to authorized AWS Organizations, OUs, and/or AWS accounts.
S3.C20.testing: Remove the policy statement blocking any IAM entity not belonging to authorized AWS Organizations, OUs, and/or AWS accounts from the VPC endpoint; it should be detected.

S3.C21.description: Enable VPC DNS query logging in all VPCs.
S3.C21.testing: Request the mechanism to enable VPC DNS query logging in all VPCs.

S3.C22.description: Maintain a list of authorized S3 and S3 access points (and their respective AWS accounts) to be accessed for each VPC.
S3.C22.testing: Request the list of authorized S3 buckets and S3 access points to be accessed for each VPC, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C23.description: Limit the access to only authorized S3 bucket(s) or their AWS account(s) from each VPC (e.g., using the condition key "s3:ResourceAccount" on the VPC endpoint policy, alternatively use a specific resource-level statement for each bucket, or if the VPC endpoint policy size is beyond the limit and more granular control on VPC is required, use access points).
S3.C23.testing: Make a request to an unauthorized bucket from one of your VPCs; it should be denied.

S3.C24.description: Verify all VPCs are limited to accessing only authorized S3 bucket(s).
S3.C24.testing: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized S3 bucket(s); it should be detected.

S3.C25.description: Monitor VPC DNS query logs to ensure only authorized S3 buckets and S3 access points are being queried in each VPC (e.g., using VPC DNS query logging) and protect them using Route 53 ThreatModel.
S3.C25.testing: Make a DNS query to an unauthorized 1) S3 bucket and 2) S3 access points; it should be detected.

S3.C26.description: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the use of non-object-related S3 actions.
S3.C26.testing: Request the list of authorized IAM principals with the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C27.description: In the S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda Access Point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM policies, and not resource policies such as S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda Access Point policies, should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.
S3.C27.testing: Request all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda Access Point policy statements with "allow"; no principal from the same account should be authorized.

S3.C28.description: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda Access Point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g., using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy).
S3.C28.testing: Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in 1) a bucket policy, 2) an access point policy, and 3) an Object Lambda Access Point; it should be detected.

S3.C29.description: Use an unguessable naming convention for the email addresses of your AWS accounts (e.g., add a + sign and a random string to redirect the email to the same mailbox).
S3.C29.testing: Review the naming convention for root account email and its implementation.

S3.C30.description: Use an unguessable naming convention for your IAM users and IAM roles (e.g., add a random string).
S3.C30.testing: Review the naming convention for IAM users/roles and their implementation.

S3.C31.description: Maintain a list of AWS accounts authorized to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account.
S3.C31.testing: Request the list of AWS accounts authorized to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C32.description: Block requests with a KMS key from an unauthorized AWS account (e.g., using an SCP, bucket policies, centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, or VPC endpoints with a deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS account).
S3.C32.testing: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from an unauthorized AWS account; it should be denied.

S3.C33.description: Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts provide KMS keys for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in "response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id").
S3.C33.testing: Encrypt an object using an unauthorized key; it should be detected.

S3.C34.description: Deny requests to change object ACL to public (e.g., using an SCP, bucket policies, centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, or VPC endpoint policy with a deny statement on PutObjectAcl for "s3:x-amz-grant-read", "s3:x-amz-grant-read-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-write-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-full-control" on the following predefined groups "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AllUsers" and "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AuthenticatedUsers").
S3.C34.testing: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL; it should be denied.

S3.C35.description: Monitor ObjectACL changes (or tentative changes) to public using CloudTrail S3 data events.
S3.C35.testing: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL; it should be detected.

S3.C36.description: Verify the control blocking change ObjectACL to public (e.g., an SCP and VPC endpoint policy) is properly implemented.
S3.C36.testing: Remove the control blocking changes of ObjectACL to public; it should be detected.

S3.C37.description: Monitor and investigate anonymous requests to objects (e.g., using CloudTrail S3 data events with userIdentity.accountId=ANONYMOUS_PRINCIPAL).
S3.C37.testing: Make an anonymous call; it should be detected.

S3.C38.description: Block the action "s3:DeleteBucket" (e.g., via SCP or in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account; exemption can be managed by authorizing a SuperAdmin to delete buckets with a certain tag, and with bucket owners able to tag buckets).
S3.C38.testing: Do a DeleteBucket; it should be denied.

S3.C39.description: Verify the control blocking the action "s3:DeleteBucket" is properly implemented.
S3.C39.testing: Remove the control blocking the action "s3:DeleteBucket"; it should be detected.

S3.C40.description: Scan your CNAME records (e.g., in Amazon Route 53) and CloudFront origin for deleted buckets.
S3.C40.testing: Create a CNAME record and CloudFront origin with an invalid bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C41.description: Parameterize the S3 bucket name or S3 access point in your code (no hardcoding).
S3.C41.testing: Request the process ensuring S3 bucket names or S3 access points are not hard-coded.

S3.C42.description: When connecting to S3 endpoints, use the virtual-hosted model ("my-bucket-name.s3.amazonaws.com" or "my-bucket-name.my-s3-regional-endpoint.amazonaws.com") instead of the path-style model ("s3.amazonaws.com/my-bucket-name" or "my-s3-regional-endpoint.amazonaws.com/my-bucket-name") (see ref). All the latest SDKs make use of domain style by default.
S3.C42.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring the use of domain style instead of path style.

S3.C43.description: Monitor that all S3 connections are made with the virtual-hosted model (e.g., via CloudTrail S3 requestParameters.Host).
S3.C43.testing: Make a path-style request to S3; it should be detected.

S3.C44.description: Ensure the integrity of stored objects (ref), using "x-amz-checksum" from the object metadata instead of ETag (e.g., using the compute checksum functionality in S3 Batch Operations). If ETag is used, make sure to properly account for its different definitions (ref).
S3.C44.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring the integrity of stored objects using checksums instead of ETag, and otherwise ensuring ETag's different definitions are properly accounted for, and 2) plan to move any older system using ETag to use the checksum metadata.

S3.C45.description: Do not include sensitive data in bucket names, access point names, object names, object metadata, and tags.
S3.C45.testing: Request the process ensuring no sensitive data is included in bucket names, object names, object metadata, and tags.

S3.C46.description: Ensure all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account (e.g., using the condition in all compatible S3 requests: x-amz-expected-bucket-owner and x-amz-source-expected-bucket-owner).
S3.C46.testing: Request the process ensuring that all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account.

S3.C47.description: Front buckets that are required to be public, using authenticated CDN (e.g., CloudFront) or API Gateway, protected with WAF (e.g., for hotlinking).
S3.C47.testing: Request the process ensuring that buckets required to be public are fronted by an authenticated CDN or API Gateway, and are protected with a WAF.

S3.C48.description: Verify no bucket is available publicly for write or read (e.g., using the AWS Config rules: S3_BUCKET_PUBLIC_READ_PROHIBITED and S3_BUCKET_PUBLIC_WRITE_PROHIBITED).
S3.C48.testing: Create a public S3 bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C49.description: Enable account-level S3 Block Public Access on all AWS accounts, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.
S3.C49.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring account-level S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all AWS accounts, 2) its records of execution for all new AWS accounts, and 3) the plan to move any older AWS accounts.

S3.C50.description: Verify account-level S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all AWS accounts, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true (e.g., using the AWS Config rule: S3_ACCOUNT_LEVEL_PUBLIC_ACCESS_BLOCKS).
S3.C50.testing: Remove the account-level S3 Block Public Access of an AWS account; it should be detected.

S3.C51.description: Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 buckets, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true (enabled by default for all new buckets after April 2023).
S3.C51.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring S3 Block Public Access is enabled on each bucket, 2) its records of execution for all new buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older buckets.

S3.C52.description: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 buckets, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true (e.g., using the AWS Config rule: S3_BUCKET_LEVEL_PUBLIC_ACCESS_PROHIBITED).
S3.C52.testing: Remove the S3 Block Public Access from an S3 bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C53.description: Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.
S3.C53.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring S3 Block Public Access is enabled on each S3 access point, 2) its records of execution for all new S3 access points, and 3) the plan to move any older S3 access points.

S3.C54.description: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.
S3.C54.testing: Remove S3 Block Public Access of 1) an access point, and 2) a Multi-Region Access Point; it should be detected.

S3.C55.description: Deny requests to add an ACL on a bucket (e.g., using an SCP, bucket policies, centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, or VPC endpoint policy, with a deny statement on "s3:PutBucketAcl").
S3.C55.testing: Make a call to add an ACL on a bucket; it should be denied.

S3.C56.description: Monitor changes to bucket ACLs to ensure they stay private (e.g., using the CloudTrail event PutBucketAcl and its field requestParameters.x-amz-acl, which should either be "private" or not exist).
S3.C56.testing: Make a call to have a bucket ACL other than private; it should be detected.

S3.C57.description: Verify the control blocking bucket ACL changes is properly implemented.
S3.C57.testing: Remove the control blocking bucket ACL changes; it should be detected.

S3.C58.description: Track all buckets you control, define their data classification and their access control (e.g., ABAC or not), identify whether the hosted data is primary (i.e., the source of truth, for example, logs, backups, forensic data, raw data, etc.) or an input/output of a process (e.g., file-processing, software package), their WORM requirements (e.g., SEC 17a-4, CTCC), whether they are production or non-production (preferably done at account-level), their storage class, their logging requirements (e.g., server access log, CloudTrail S3 data events), and their dual-layer server-side encryption requirement (e.g., for NSA CNSSP 15, or DAR CP). You may use tags, Infra-as-code, AWS Glue Data Catalog, or external management tools like FINRA herd.
S3.C58.testing: Request the list of all buckets you control and their related requirements, and the mechanism and records to ensure the accuracy of that metadata.

S3.C59.description: Use a data discovery tool (e.g., Amazon Macie) to ensure no sensitive data is stored in an unauthorized bucket.
S3.C59.testing: Upload higher classification data in a bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C60.description: Use a data discovery tool (e.g., Amazon Macie) to ensure the bucket names, object names, tags, and metadata do not contain sensitive data.
S3.C60.testing: Create a bucket name, object name, tags, or metadata of an object with sensitive data; it should be detected.

S3.C61.description: Maintain a list of authorized KMS keys for each bucket and its default encryption key. You might simplify by using only one key per bucket, ideally dedicated. Note that an S3 server access log bucket does not support KMS encryption (ref).
S3.C61.testing: Request the list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C62.description: Verify all objects in S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key (e.g., using S3 Inventory or S3 Batch Operations, see blog, or S3 Storage Lens, UnencryptedObjectCount and SSEKMSEnabledBucketCount).
S3.C62.testing: Upload encrypted data 1) using an unauthorized KMS key, or 2) using SSE-S3; it should be detected.

S3.C63.description: Use KMS ThreatModel to protect the KMS keys used for S3 (e.g., using encryptionContext on the policy of each KMS key).
S3.C63.testing: Request the KMS ThreatModel and the evidence of its application to protect S3.

S3.C64.description: Implement an authorized default encryption key on each bucket; enable S3 Bucket Key if not using DSSE-KMS and if CloudTrail events are not required for KMS encrypt/decrypt (note: Amazon S3 evaluates and applies bucket policies before applying bucket default encryption settings).
S3.C64.testing: Request 1) the mechanism implementing an authorized default encryption key on each bucket and enabling S3 Bucket Key, 2) its records of execution for all new buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older buckets.

S3.C65.description: Verify each bucket has an authorized default encryption key and has S3 Bucket Key enabled.
S3.C65.testing: Create/modify a bucket 1) without default encryption, 2) with an incorrect default encryption key, or 3) with S3 Bucket Key disabled; it should be detected.

S3.C66.description: Block PutObject requests with unauthorized KMS key on each bucket (e.g., using their bucket policy, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with a deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" exists and is not an authorized KMS key).
S3.C66.testing: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key; it should be denied.

S3.C67.description: Verify all buckets block PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key (e.g., using the Config rule: S3_BUCKET_POLICY_NOT_MORE_PERMISSIVE, note that a new rule needs to be deployed for each configuration, then the resource tracked by name or tag; alternatively, you might use S3_BUCKET_SERVER_SIDE_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED to ensure limited coverage).
S3.C67.testing: Create a bucket not blocking PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key; it should be detected.

S3.C68.description: Monitor that only authorized KMS keys are used for each bucket (using CloudTrail S3 data events in "requestParameters.bucketName" and "response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id").
S3.C68.testing: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key; it should be detected.

S3.C69.description: Enable versioning on buckets holding primary data.
S3.C69.testing: Request the mechanism used to ensure versioning on buckets holding primary data, and its records.

S3.C70.description: Verify buckets holding primary data are versioned (e.g., using S3_BUCKET_VERSIONING_ENABLED).
S3.C70.testing: Remove versioning from a bucket holding primary data; it should be detected.

S3.C71.description: Back up primary data in a secure location under a different security authority (e.g., in an AWS data bunker account via replication, or using AWS Backup for Amazon S3).
S3.C71.testing: Request the mechanism used to back up primary data in a location that has a different security authority, its records of execution, and its records of restoration testing.

S3.C72.description: Aligned with your data governance, encrypt on the client side - or tokenize - the appropriate data.
S3.C72.testing: Request the governance and mechanism(s) used to protect data (e.g., encrypt or tokenize critical data on the client side).

S3.C73.description: Create a process to apply a legal hold to any S3 bucket whenever required. The condition "s3:object-lock-legal-hold" can be used to restrict who can remove such a lock.
S3.C73.testing: Request the process of applying legal hold, and its records.

S3.C74.description: Implement the authorized default S3 Object Lock on buckets requiring WORM (note: Amazon S3 evaluates and applies bucket policies before applying the bucket default S3 Object Lock settings).
S3.C74.testing: Upload an object without the appropriate S3 Object Lock; it should have the S3 Object Lock applied automatically.

S3.C75.description: Verify all buckets requiring WORM have the correct default S3 Object Lock configuration.
S3.C75.testing: Create a bucket requiring WORM 1) without S3 Object Lock or 2) with an incorrect default S3 Object Lock; it should be detected.

S3.C76.description: Block PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock on buckets requiring WORM (e.g., using their bucket policy and centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or the AWS account with a deny statement on PutObject and PutObjectRetention if the condition "s3:object-lock-mode" exists and "s3:object-lock-remaining-retention-days" is not the defined S3 Object Lock configuration).
S3.C76.testing: Make a request with an incorrect S3 Object Lock configuration on a bucket requiring WORM; it should be denied.

S3.C77.description: Verify all buckets requiring WORM block PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock (e.g., using the Config rule: S3_BUCKET_POLICY_NOT_MORE_PERMISSIVE, note that a new rule needs to be deployed for each configuration, then the resource tracked by name or tag).
S3.C77.testing: Create a bucket requiring WORM that does not block PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock; it should be detected.

S3.C78.description: Reduce costs related to incomplete multipart uploads by creating a lifecycle policy to remove them after an agreed length of time (e.g., 7 days) (blog).
S3.C78.testing: Create an incomplete upload, and wait for the agreed time; it should be deleted automatically.

S3.C79.description: Verify a lifecycle policy on incomplete multipart uploads is implemented on all buckets (e.g., using AWS Config rule: S3_LIFECYCLE_POLICY_CHECK).
S3.C79.testing: Create a bucket without a lifecycle policy to remove incomplete multipart uploads; it should be detected.

S3.C80.description: Block deprecated S3 actions using IAM ThreatModel and the S3 actions list.
S3.C80.testing: Request the controls blocking deprecated S3 actions.

S3.C81.description: Block all requests not using SigV4 (e.g., using an SCP, bucket policies, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account on all buckets with deny on "StringNotEquals":{"s3:signatureversion": "AWS4-HMAC-SHA256"}).
S3.C81.testing: Make a non-SigV4 AWS API call; it should be denied.

S3.C82.description: Monitor and investigate any requests not using SigV4 (e.g., via CloudTrail S3 when the additionalEventData.SignatureVersion is different from "SigV4").
S3.C82.testing: Make a non-SigV4 AWS API call; it should be detected.

S3.C83.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring the use of SDK with SigV4 enabled.

S3.C84.description: Block all requests not using HTTP authorization header, i.e., presigned via query strings or POST (ref) (e.g., using an SCP, bucket policies, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account on all buckets with deny on "StringNotEquals":{"s3:authType": "REST-HEADER"}). Note that it blocks uploads via the console, as well.
S3.C84.testing: Make a request without using the HTTP authorization header; it should be denied.

S3.C85.description: Monitor and investigate all requests that do not use the HTTP authorization header (e.g., via CloudTrail S3 events where the additionalEventData.AuthenticationMethod is different from "AuthHeader").
S3.C85.testing: Make 1) a presigned AWS API call and 2) a POST request without the HTTP authorization header; it should be detected.

S3.C86.description: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to have replication enabled, their target bucket, and replication type (i.e., encryption type, ownership, RTC, etc.) (ref).
S3.C86.testing: Request the list of authorized buckets to have replication enabled, their target bucket and replication rights, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C87.description: Verify only authorized buckets have replication enabled with their correct configuration (e.g., using S3 Storage Lens CrossAccountReplicationRuleCount).
S3.C87.testing: Configure replication on a non-authorized bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C88.description: Verify authorized buckets have the correct replication configuration.
S3.C88.testing: Modify the configuration of an authorized replication; it should be detected.

S3.C89.description: Maintain a list of IAM roles used for replication, ideally dedicated (e.g., using change management process on infrastructure-as-code).
S3.C89.testing: Request the list of all IAM roles configured for replication.

S3.C90.description: Limit S3 access to the source and destination buckets and the replication rights of each authorized IAM role configured for replication.
S3.C90.testing: Request the S3 access for each replication role, and how they align with the replication requirements.

S3.C91.description: Limit access to authorized IAM roles used for replication, using the IAM ThreatModel (e.g., trust policy, and "iam:PassRole").
S3.C91.testing: Request the IAM ThreatModel and the evidence of its application to the IAM roles used for replication.

S3.C92.description: Verify only the authorized IAM role is configured for each replication.
S3.C92.testing: Create/modify a replication with an unauthorized IAM role; it should be detected.

S3.C93.description: If the bucket is used as an input or the output of a process, scan the objects for malware (e.g., using GuardDuty Malware Protection for S3, BucketAV, Cloud Storage Security, Trend Micro Cloud One, or your own scanning solution).
S3.C93.testing: Inject a malware test file; it should be detected.

S3.C94.description: Maintain a list of authorized notification receivers (e.g., SNS topic, Lambda) for each bucket. You might use a simpler approach by using authorized account IDs to ensure all your receivers are in authorized AWS accounts.
S3.C94.testing: Request the list of authorized notification receivers for each bucket, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C95.description: Verify only authorized notification receiver(s) are configured for buckets.
S3.C95.testing: Create an unauthorized receiver; it should be detected.

S3.C96.description: Maintain a list of authorized S3 buckets to receive the S3 Inventory of each bucket.
S3.C96.testing: Request the list of authorized bucket(s) to receive S3 Inventory of each bucket, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C97.description: Verify only authorized buckets are configured to receive inventory.
S3.C97.testing: Create an unauthorized bucket to receive inventory; it should be detected.

S3.C98.description: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPCs authorized to access it.
S3.C98.testing: For each S3 bucket, request the list of authorized VPCs to access it, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C99.description: Limit access to only authorized VPCs (e.g., using their bucket policy, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with a deny statement if the condition "aws:SourceVpce" is met, or if the bucket policy size is beyond the limit, use this condition on the access point).
S3.C99.testing: Make a request to the bucket outside an authorized VPC; it should be denied.

S3.C100.description: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPCs (e.g., using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK).
S3.C100.testing: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized VPC(s); it should be detected.

S3.C101.description: Maintain a list of authorized CloudFront distributions (via Origin Access Control) and associated bucket, access point, and/or Object Lambda Access Point.
S3.C101.testing: Request the list of all authorized CloudFront distributions and associated S3 buckets, access points, and/or Object Lambda Access Points.

S3.C102.description: Verify all associations of CloudFront distributions with buckets, access points, and/or Object Lambda Access Points are authorized (e.g., using the Macie finding: "Policy:IAMUser/S3BucketSharedWithCloudFront").
S3.C102.testing: Create a non-authorized distribution or association; it should be detected.

S3.C103.description: Protect and/or claim your domains and trademarks/copyrights (by creating your trademark buckets and using the copyright infringement process from AWS).
S3.C103.testing: Request the process by protecting and/or claiming your domains and trademarks/copyrights.

S3.C104.description: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPCs, S3 access points, and S3.
S3.C104.testing: Request the list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access points, and S3.

S3.C105.description: Limit access via the S3 access point by using a VPC endpoint, bucket policy, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn" in an allow statement to reduce the length of the allowlist bucket name in the VPC endpoint/bucket policy.
S3.C105.testing: Make a request on an unauthorized access point or bucket; it should be denied.

S3.C106.description: In bucket policies, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, deny all IAM principals not using an authorized S3 access point(s) using the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn".
S3.C106.testing: Query the bucket outside the S3 access point; it should be denied.

S3.C107.description: Block the creation of non-VPC S3 access point "s3:CreateAccessPoint" (e.g., using IAM policies and SCPs with the condition "StringNotEquals": {"s3:AccessPointNetworkOrigin": "VPC"}).
S3.C107.testing: Make a request to create an internet-based access point; it should be denied.

S3.C108.description: Block all traffic from Internet-configured S3 access points (e.g., in their bucket policy, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, using a deny statement with the condition "StringNotEquals": {"s3:AccessPointNetworkOrigin": "VPC"}).
S3.C108.testing: Create an internet-facing access point and try to access a bucket; it should be denied.

S3.C109.description: Verify only access points are used in the resource-level statements in VPC endpoints.
S3.C109.testing: Create a VPC endpoint giving access to an S3 bucket directly, rather than an access point; it should be detected.

S3.C110.description: Verify S3 bucket policies deny unauthorized S3 access points.
S3.C110.testing: Remove/modify the deny on the bucket policy; it should be detected.

S3.C111.description: Verify all S3 access points are VPC-attached.
S3.C111.testing: Create an internet-based access point; it should be detected.

S3.C112.description: Block any object-related operations access to S3 buckets not through an access point (i.e., IAM policy, SCP, their bucket policy, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with a deny statement on the condition "ArnNotLike": {"s3:DataAccessPointArn": "arn:aws:s3:Region:AccountId:accesspoint/*"}).
S3.C112.testing: Access any S3 bucket without using an access point; it should be denied.

S3.C113.description: When transmitting an object to an external bucket with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirements but without S3 Object Ownership handover, use 2 separate APIs (PutObject and PutObjectAcl) instead of the built-in object ACL operation in PutObject.
S3.C113.testing: Request the process for ensuring that PutObject requests on an external bucket with a bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement, but without S3 Object Ownership handover, use 2 separate APIs.

S3.C114.description: For all external buckets with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover, block the PutObject with any ACL (e.g., using IAM or SCP and a deny on the condition "StringLike": {"s3:x-amz-acl": "*"}). It should be called via PutObjectAcl.
S3.C114.testing: Put an object in an external bucket with the bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without the S3 Object Ownership handover requirement; it should be denied.

S3.C115.description: For all external buckets with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirements but without S3 Object Ownership handover, monitor that the PutObject operation does not include the ACL header.
S3.C115.testing: Make a request to an external bucket with a bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without an S3 Object Ownership handover requirement; it should be detected.

S3.C116.description: Monitor abnormal behavior on replication CloudWatch metrics (i.e., "BytesPendingReplication", "OperationsPendingReplication", and "OperationsFailedReplication").
S3.C116.testing: Create an abnormal replication, or block a replication; it should be detected.

S3.C117.description: Verify all replicated buckets have metrics enabled on each replication rule (included by default in S3 RTC).
S3.C117.testing: Modify the replication metric of an authorized replication; it should be detected.

S3.C118.description: Enable S3 policy findings in Amazon Macie in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect them using the Macie ThreatModel.
S3.C118.testing: Request the Macie ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 policy findings.

S3.C119.description: Maintain a list of authorized version(s) of TLS/SSL per bucket (or per account/OU/Org) (e.g., considering quantum-resistant encryption).
S3.C119.testing: Request the list of authorized version(s) of TLS/SSL per bucket (or per account/OU/Org), its review mechanism, and associated records.

S3.C120.description: Maintain a list of IAM roles used for Batch jobs, ideally dedicated (e.g., using change management process on infrastructure-as-code).
S3.C120.testing: Request the list of all IAM roles configured for Batch jobs.

S3.C121.description: Limit access to only the required resources/permissions (e.g., source/destination buckets, Lambda functions) for each authorized IAM role configured for Batch jobs.
S3.C121.testing: Request access only to the required resources/permissions for each Batch IAM role, and request information on how they are aligned with the replication requirements.

S3.C122.description: Limit access to authorized IAM roles used for Batch jobs, using the IAM ThreatModel (e.g., trust policy, and "iam:PassRole").
S3.C122.testing: Request the IAM ThreatModel and the evidence of its application to the IAM roles used for Batch jobs.

S3.C123.description: Verify only the authorized IAM role is configured for each Batch job.
S3.C123.testing: Create/modify a Batch job with an unauthorized IAM role; it should be detected.

S3.C124.description: Ensure all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoint controls.
S3.C124.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls, 2) its records of execution for all new VPC endpoints, and 3) the plan to move any older VPC endpoints.

S3.C125.description: Maintain a list of authorized Lambda functions for each Object Lambda Access Point, its associated access point, its associated HEAD/LIST/GET request(s), and payload.
S3.C125.testing: Request the list of authorized Lambda functions for each Object Lambda Access Point, its associated access point, its associated HEAD/LIST/GET request(s), and payload, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C126.description: Ensure only authorized Lambda functions for each Object Lambda Access Point, its associated access point, its associated HEAD/LIST/GET request(s), and payload are created.
S3.C126.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring only authorized Lambda functions for each Object Lambda Access Point, its associated access point, its associated HEAD/LIST/GET request(s), and payload, and the evidence of its execution.

S3.C127.description: Verify only the authorized Lambda functions are configured on each Object Lambda Access Point, its associated access point, its associated HEAD/LIST/GET request(s), and payload.
S3.C127.testing: Attach 1) an unauthorized Lambda function to an Object Lambda Access Point, 2) an unauthorized Object Lambda Access Point to an access point, 3) an authorized Lambda function with an unauthorized HEAD/LIST/GET request to an Object Lambda Access Point, and 4) an authorized Lambda function with an unauthorized payload; it should be detected.

S3.C128.description: Ensure Lambda functions configured on Object Lambda Access Point are secured using Lambda ThreatModel.
S3.C128.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring Lambda ThreatModel and its application for Lambda functions associated with Object Lambda Access Points, and its records of execution.

S3.C129.description: Maintain a list of cross-account access on each Object Lambda Access Point.
S3.C129.testing: Request the list of authorized cross-account access for each Object Lambda Access Point, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C130.description: Ensure only authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda Access Point policy.
S3.C130.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring only cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda Access Point policy, and the evidence of its execution.

S3.C131.description: Verify only the authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda Access Point policy.
S3.C131.testing: Add an unauthorized cross-account IAM entity on an Object Lambda Access Point policy; it should be detected.

S3.C132.description: Ensure CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda Access Points.
S3.C132.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda Access Points, and its records of execution.

S3.C133.description: Verify CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda Access Points.
S3.C133.testing: Create an Object Lambda Access Point without CloudWatch enabled; it should be detected.

S3.C134.description: Ensure only authorized buckets have replication enabled and are configured correctly.
S3.C134.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring only authorized buckets have replication enabled with their correct configuration, 2) its records of execution for all new buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older buckets.

S3.C135.description: Ensure only authorized notification receivers for each bucket are configured.
S3.C135.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring only authorized notification receivers for each bucket are configured, 2) its records of execution for all new buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older buckets.

S3.C136.description: Ensure only authorized S3 buckets are configured to receive S3 Inventory for each bucket.
S3.C136.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring only authorized S3 buckets are configured to receive S3 Inventory for each bucket, 2) its records of execution for all new buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older buckets.

S3.C137.description: Ensure only authorized CloudFront distributions are associated with their authorized bucket, access point, and/or Object Lambda Access Point; and vice versa (e.g., using their bucket policy, centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with a deny statement, access point policy, resource policy for an Object Lambda Access Point, limiting the access to only the authorized distribution(s) in the SourceArn).
S3.C137.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring only authorized CloudFront distributions are associated with their authorized bucket, access point, and/or Object Lambda Access Point; and vice versa, 2) its records of execution for all new CloudFront distributions, and 3) the plan to move any older CloudFront distributions.

S3.C138.description: Ensure only authorized IAM roles are attached for each replication, ideally dedicated.
S3.C138.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring authorized IAM roles are attached for each replication, and the evidence of its execution for all replication configurations.

S3.C139.description: Ensure only an authorized IAM role is attached to each Batch job.
S3.C139.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring only an authorized IAM role is attached to each Batch job, and the evidence of its execution for all new {resource}.

S3.C140.description: Ensure all objects in S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key.
S3.C140.testing: Request the mechanism (including training or utility) ensuring only authorized KMS keys are used for any objects stored in S3.

S3.C141.description: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to be configured as an S3 website endpoint.
S3.C141.testing: Request the list of authorized buckets to be configured as a website endpoint, its review process, and its review records.

S3.C142.description: Ensure only authorized buckets are configured as an S3 website endpoint.
S3.C142.testing: Request 1) the mechanism ensuring only authorized buckets are configured as S3 website endpoints, 2) its records of execution for all new website-enabled buckets, and 3) the plan to move any older website-enabled buckets.

S3.C143.description: Verify only authorized buckets are configured as S3 website endpoints.
S3.C143.testing: Enable static website hosting on an unauthorized bucket; it should be detected.

S3.C144.description: Ensure S3 website endpoints are protected with HTTP headers (ref) using a CDN (e.g., CloudFront).
S3.C144.testing: Request the mechanism ensuring S3 website endpoints are protected with HTTP headers.

S3.C145.description: Maintain a list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted using server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C).
S3.C145.testing: Request the list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted with server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C), its review process, and its review records.

S3.C146.description: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption (e.g., using bucket policies, or centrally in an RCP applied to the OU or AWS account, with a deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm"="AES256" is not present).
